required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effectiveness of Biofreeze® on Shoulder Pain and In-office Exercise Performance
clinical_study.official_title: Effectiveness of Biofreeze® on Shoulder Pain and In-office Exercise Performance: A Preliminary Pilot Study

lead_sponsor.agency: Sport and Spine Rehab Clinical Research Foundation

clinical_study.source: Sport and Spine Rehab Clinical Research Foundation

brief_summary.textblock: Biofreeze® is a topical analgesic, frequently used in the office or given to a patient for home use as a way to mitigate pain during the course of treatment. Rehabilitative exercises are considered an important component of care for shoulder pain patients, although pain can be a limiting factor in the advancement of rehabilitation. The purpose of this study is to evaluate the addition of Biofreeze® to an in-office group of shoulder pain patients to determine its impact on pain reduction. Methods: Patients 18-64 years old with mechanical shoulder pain who are candidates for standard shoulder therapy will be randomized into two groups (N=20). The Control group (N=10) will receive standard shoulder therapy alone while the Intervention group (N=10) will receive standard shoulder therapy plus Biofreeze® just prior to initiating the in-office exercise program. Values of pain (NPRS) and disability (ASES) will be recorded at baseline, 2 weeks, and 4 weeks. Hypotheses will be addressed by repeated measures ANOVAs within and between group, time, and interaction main effects. Clinical Relevance: Progression of therapeutic exercises can be limited by pain and the associated disability. The ability to decrease shoulder pain and disability with a topical analgesic will allow health care professionals to advance patients through a therapeutic exercise program without the restriction of pain. In turn, patients will correct the underlying condition of their shoulder pain at a faster rate.

primary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline of American Shoulder and Elbow Surgeons (ASES) Questionnaire at 2 Weeks
primary_outcome.description: The American Shoulder and Elbow Surgeons (ASES) Questionnaire is a self-report questionnaire measuring pain and disability. It is measured from 0 to 100, 0 being completely disabled and 100 being pain free and normal function. The total score is calculated using the following equation: (10-NPRS) x 5 = __ + (5/3) x Cumulative ADL Score

primary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline of Numeric Pain Rating Scale (NPRS) at 2 Weeks
primary_outcome.description: The Numeric Pain Rating Scale (NPRS) is a self-report scale measuring pain. It is measured from 0 to 10, 0 being pain free and 10 being the worse imaginable pain.

primary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline of American Shoulder and Elbow Surgeons (ASES) Questionnaire at 4 Weeks
primary_outcome.description: The American Shoulder and Elbow Surgeons (ASES) Questionnaire is a self-report questionnaire measuring pain and disability. It is measured from 0 to 100, 0 being completely disabled and 100 being pain free and normal function. The total score is calculated using the following equation: (10-NPRS) x 5 = __ + (5/3) x Cumulative ADL Score

primary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline of Numeric Pain Rating Scale (NPRS)at 4 Weeks
primary_outcome.description: The Numeric Pain Rating Scale (NPRS) is a self-report scale measuring pain. It is measured from 0 to 10, 0 being pain free and 10 being the worse imaginable pain.

arm_group.description: Apply 5 minutes before therapy by applying a small coin sized amount to the painful area. Subjects will then complete a standard shoulder therapy program.
Subjects in this arm will complete a standard shoulder therapy program as normal, with no intervention.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- 18-64 years old
- mechanical shoulder pain
- candidates for conservative care
Exclusion Criteria:
- pregnancy
- radicular symptoms
- not a candidate for conservative care
- history of recent shoulder surgery

overall_official.affiliation: Sport and Spine Rehab Clinical Research Foundation

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
